author: nishant0
content: I would disagree with this, most node runners have control over whatever disk they are running and processor they are running with. However bandwidth is something that is very much out of their control, if you live in a country with sub-optimal fibre infrastructure you are stuck with whatever low bandwidth connection your isp provides you with limited room to change. Currently running geth can take up to 5 mib/s with the default number of peers. Increasing this significantly will permanently disqualify a subset of users from ever being able to run a node.

author: potuz
content: Oh I missed this comment, now Nishant brought it back. I disagree: disk and CPU are under my control. The former are cheap and getting cheaper. Bandwidth is not. I live in a big city in a big country, and anyway internet operators are essentially a monopoly. Getting large bandwidth which is not throttled at high speed both ways and with a fixed IP is just plainly impossible unless I open a company and buy an big Enterprise package. And even then I'm at the mercy of whatever the ISP decides. I'm completely sure that this is a reality in many countries not only mine.
